Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A purchase agreement needs analysis before an upcoming filing deadline that is drawing nearer.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my siblings. Mom had sent a picture of the table set for dinner, my favorite dishes lined up, and a caption: “Don’t be late, everyone!” I could almost hear her voice, warm and expectant. As the eldest, I knew how much it meant to her when we were all together, especially after Dad passed away. But on my desk, a thick stack of legal documents waited—an urgent purchase agreement that needed my review before tomorrow’s filing deadline. My client was counting on me; any mistake could cost them dearly. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family wanted me present, laughing and sharing stories, but my client needed my focus and expertise. My heart ached at the thought of disappointing either side. I glanced at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away, torn between the comfort of home and the demands of my profession, unsure which responsibility should come first.
